title: Is it legal to scan or copy an entire book for personal use? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: Personal use allows the duplication of any media that you own—which was legally purchased or acquire. That duplicate cannot leave the house or be shared with others. And just to be clear, uploading to a cloud servers is “leaving the house”. If you think “personal use” means just reading the book, that would be wrong. That’s the normal use of a book (or a movie or TV show or song). That’s just media consumption and you cannot make copies of media for free just so you can read or enjoy it.

Do you own the book? In Belgium, it is legal to make a copy of a(ny) data carrier, be it a book, a CD, Blu-ray or DVD (or LP), as long as you own the original. (Quite irritating that all tools that make those (legally permitted) duplicates are being prosecuted because ‘they can copy things’ [DUH]). If you don’t own the original, no, it’s not legal. Not for personal, nor for other use.
